Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial my next sales lead. It was Jamie, my best friend, her name flashing on the screen. I hesitated, thumb hovering. I could hear her shaky voice through the receiver, “Can you talk? I really need someone right now.” I knew what she expected—someone to listen, to care, to help her untangle the mess of her latest fight with her partner. But glancing at the clock, I felt my stomach twist. It was the last day of the quarter, and my manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We need every sale. No exceptions.” The spreadsheet on my screen showed I was just two calls away from hitting my target, the bonus that would help with next month’s rent. My headset felt heavier than usual. Jamie’s voice was pleading, but so was the silent pressure from my job. I wanted to be the friend she needed, but I also needed to be the employee my team was counting on. My heart pounded as I stared at the blinking call, torn between picking up for Jamie or making the next sales call.
